Copy file descriptor #2 (stderr) to #1 (stdout), causing all error messages to be printed to stdout. 'man bash'.
Usually, when you use it in "command 2>&1 > somefile", it's shorter to use "command >& somefile" instead.

the script i'm studying with use this « some_command >/dev/null 2>&1 » . I'm not sure what this means. Does it means every output from the command will be located in /dev/null as well as the errors? What's /dev/null for anyway?
The normal output (stdout) is redirected to /dev/null -- in other words, discarded. Everything you write to /dev/null disappears.
And then 2>&1 redirects stderr to stdout - so it too goes to /dev/null.
In other words, everything that the program outputs is discarded.
A shorter version of the same is 'some_command >& /dev/null'
So, everything will be gone? So no error and output will be reported?
